title: Iraq War
summary: The Iraq War was a protracted armed conflict that began in 2003 with the invasion of Iraq by a United States-led coalition that overthrew the government of Saddam Hussein. The conflict continued for much of the next decade as an insurgency emerged to oppose the occupying forces and the post-invasion Iraqi government.

title: First all-transgender Vagina Monologues
summary: Deep Stealth Productions presented the V-Day 2004 Worldwide Campaign event for Los Angeles on Saturday, February 21st. In cooperation with the author, internationally-known playwright Eve Ensler, and under the auspices of Jane Fonda, this benefit performance featured the first ever transgender cast of “The Vagina Monologues,” and included a new monologue written by Eve especially for this event

title: Art & Collaboration
summary: Develops collaborative art projects with first love

title: Barack Obama is Elected, America’s First Black President
summary: Barack Obama, a Democrat from Illinois, was elected President of the United States on November 4, 2008 and was inaugurated as the nation's 44th president on January 20, 2009

title: The first International Transgender Day of Visibility is held
summary: Founded by transgender activist Rachel Crandall of Michigan in 2009 as a reaction to the lack of LGBT recognition of transgender people, citing the frustration that the only well-known transgender-centered day was the Transgender Day of Remembrance, which mourned the murders of transgender people, but did not acknowledge and celebrate living members of the transgender community. The first International Transgender Day of Visibility was held on March 31, 2009.

title: Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010
summary: The Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010 (H.R. 2965, S. 4023) is a landmark United States federal statute enacted in December 2010 that established a process for ending the 'don't ask, don't tell' (DADT) policy (10 U.S.C. § 654), thus allowing gay, lesbian, and bisexual people to serve openly in the United States Armed Forces. It ended the policy in place since 1993 that allowed them to serve only if they kept their sexual orientation secret and the military did not learn of their sexual orientation, which was controversial.Don’t ask Don’t Tell is repealed

title: Testosterone
summary: Starts hormone replacement therapy

title: Name Change
summary: Goes to court to legally change name

title: Keene State College Alumni Art Exhibition
summary: Group Show, selections by Prof. Lynn Richardson, Carroll House Gallery

title: Obama invokes gay rights in inaugural address
summary: President Obama, became the first president to use the word “gay” as a reference to sexual orientation in an inaugural address, declaring the movement for equality to be part of the pantheon of America’s great civil rights struggles. 'Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law,” the president said. “For if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal, as well.'

title: Surgery 1
summary: Tonsillectomy

title: Surgery 2
summary: Chest reconstruction surgery (top surgery), freedom and affirmation.

title: Gender Signifier
summary: Legally changes gender signifier to male on all records.

title: Beginnings of transgender bathroom access wars
summary: June 2013 - The Colorado Civil Rights Division ruled in favor of 6-year-old transgender student Coy Mathis to use the girls’ bathroom at her elementary school. It was the first ruling of its kind in the United States and one of the first high-profile transgender rights cases, garnering huge amounts of media attention.

title: Surgery 3
summary: Top surgery revision, insufficient funds for anesthesia - surgery completed with local anesthetic, most painful experience to date.

summary: Accepted into MFA program at Georgia State University 'GSU'

title: Atlanta
summary: Packs up Subaru and moves to Atlanta

summary: Begins graduate studies at GSU

title: Same-sex marriage is made legal nationwide with Obergefell v. Hodges decision
summary: On June 26, 2015, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down all state bans on same-sex marriage, legalized it in all fifty states, and required states to honor out-of-state same-sex marriage licenses in the case Obergefell v. Hodges.

title: 37th Annual Juried Art Exhibition
summary: January 16 - March 13, 2016, Juried by Monmouth Museum

title: American Road Trip
summary: January 20 - February 19, 2016, Juried by Site: Brooklyn

title: North Carolina passes HB 2, restricting access to bathrooms and other facilities
summary: March 23, 2016 - North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory (R) signed into law the Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act (commonly known as House Bill 2 or HB2). The law states that in government buildings, individuals (such as students at stateoperated schools) may only use restrooms and changing facilities that correspond to the sex identified on their birth certificates.

title: The US DoJ and the US Dept of Education released a joint guidance on the application of Title IX protections to transgender students.
summary: May 2016 - The United States Department of Justice and the United States Department of Education released a joint guidance on the application of Title IX protections to transgender students. The guidance stated that for the purpose of Title IX, the Department of Justice and the Department of Education treat a student’s gender identity as their sex. Officials from the Justice and Education Departments issue a memo to all school districts concerning discrimination in schools. The memo announces that unless schools uphold the Obama administration’s trans-inclusive interpretation of Title IX, they risk being confronted with a lawsuit or loss of funding.

title: Deans' List
place: Thomas Deans Fine Art, Atlanta, Georgia
summary: July 22 - July 30, 2016 'Faculty Selections of MFA Student Works from Florida State University and Georgia State University: featuring some of the best young artists in the South.'

title: Federal judge temporarily halts Obama’s directive to schools on accommodating transgender students
summary: August 2016 - Judge Reed O’Connor in Texas halts enforcement of the Obama administration’s directive for allowing transgender students to use the bathroom corresponding with their gender identity. The Trump administration later decides not to intervene.

title: Deans' List
summary: November 3 - November 17, 2016, Juried by the Art Student Union at Georgia State University

title: Identity Crisis
summary: December 2 - December 3, 2016, Juried by Kirstin Mitchell

title: Aqua Art Miami
summary: November 30 - December 4, 2016, Group show, hosted by the Aqua Hotel in conjunction with Art Basel in Miami

title: Trump Administration Rescinds Obama Rule On Transgender Students' Bathroom Use
summary: February 2017 - President Trump revokes the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX that protects transgender students from discrimination based on gender, putting the Trump administration at odds with several federal courts that have concluded that Title IX does protect trans students.

title: Partial repeal of HB2
summary: March 30, 2017 - The NC legislature partially repealed HB2, removing the restrictions on restroom use by transgender individuals. The compromise agreement was heavily criticized.

title: A Few Weeks, Maybe Months... | MFA Thesis Exhibition
place: Welch School Galleries, Georgia State University, Atlanta, Georgia
summary: March 20 - March 24, 2017. A few weeks, maybe months… is an exhibition of photographs that contemplates the societal expectations of the gender binary in the context of travel. The work considers the intersection of manhood with transgender identity and examines definitions of masculinity and gender. The American road trip is historically a masculine rite of passage which, in this case, will never fully be realized. Discrepancies in imagery throughout the work interrupt the conventional narrative structure of the road trip. Acknowledging that the acquisition of masculinity is a futile act, the journey then becomes a complex act of reconciliation.

title: Bearing Witness
place: Gallery 303, Georgia Southern University, Statesboro, Georgia
summary: April 5 - May 5, 2017 - Group show curated by Kirstie Tepper.

title: Digital Divide
place: Midtown Player's Club at Colony Square, Atlanta, Georgia
summary: May 20 - June 2, 2017- Group show curated by Kris Pilcher and Miranda Kyle.

title: Trifecta
place: Welch School Galleries, Georgia State University, Atlanta, Georgia
summary: May 12 - September 22, 2017 - Juried by Ridley Howard, exhibition featuring selected MFA candidates from three Georgia universities.

title: Begins Teaching
summary: Begins part time teaching positions at Oglethorpe University and Piedmont College.

title: Trifecta
place: Atlanta Photography Group, Tula Art Center, Atlanta, Georgia
summary: October 7 - November 12, 2017- Juried by Gregory Harris (Assistant Curator of Photography for the High Museum of Art in Atlanta)

title: Federal courts rule in favor of transgender students in two cases.
summary: July 2018 - In Florida, a U.S. District Court ruled that, by denying Drew Adams access to the boys’ room, a local school board had violated his right to equal protection of the law under the Constitution’s Fourteenth Amendment, as well as violating Title IX. The U.S. Court of Appeals upheld a Pennsylvania school district’s decision to implement a trans-inclusive restroom policy in the Doe v. Boyertown case.

title: First full-time teaching position
summary: Begins full-time teaching position at Piedmont College as a Visting Professor of Art.

title: Owl Artists Fly Home | Alumni Art Exhibition
place: Centennial Hall, Barry Alumni House, Keene State College, Keene, New Hampshire
summary: Saturday, September 15, 2018

title: Assistant Professor
summary: After another year of interviews receives Assitant Professor title and full-time teaching position at Piedmont College.

title: Minneapolis College of Art & Design
summary: As a condition of employment begins taking courses towards Masters in Graphic and Web Design.

title: Doctors scramble to identify mysterious illness emerging in China
summary: January 7, 2020 - At least 59 people in China have become ill with a mysterious pneumonia – seven of whom are in a serious condition, according to a local health commission. Chinese authorities still don’t know what has caused the outbreak, but have ruled out SARS, MERS and bird flu.

title: The WHO is now calling the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic
summary: March 11, 2020 - The World Health Organization today said the covid-19 outbreak caused by coronavirus is now  classed as a pandemic.

title: Trump declares national emergency over coronavirus
summary: March 13, 2020 - The emergency declaration will free up as much as $50 billion in financial resources to efforts by states and U.S. territories to assist Americans affected by the outbreak.

title: Supreme Court Finds Title VII Protects LGBTQ Individuals From Workplace Discrimination
summary: June 15, 2020. - The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that workplace discrimination because of an individual’s sexual orientation or gender identity — including being transgender — is unlawful discrimination “because of sex” under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Transgender student Gavin Grimm's battle over bathroom access
summary: August 26, 2020. - After a five-Year legal journey, a federal judge finds in favor of Gavin Grimm, a transgender student in Virginia who sued the school board in June 2015, for prohibiting him from using the boys’ restrooms. Gavin asserted that the school board’s insistence on his using bathrooms corresponding to his biological sex constituted sex discrimination and a violation of the law. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed the ruling in favor of Gavin on August 26, 2020.

title: COVID vaccine
summary: March 2021 - Receives first round of COVID vaccine.
